title: Grade 7 Mathematics
teaser: Ratios and Proportional Relationships, The Number System, Expressions and Equations

children.title: Ratios and Proportional Relationship
children.teaser: Students continue practice with ratios, unit rates, and fraction division to analyze proportional relationships.

children.title: Proportional Relationships
children.teaser: Students are reintroduced to ratio value, equivalent ratios, rate, and unit rate through collaborative work.

children.title: An Experience in Relationships as Measuring Rate
children.teaser: Students will write ratios, equivalent ratios, rates, and unit rates.

children.title: Identify Proportional Relationships
children.teaser: Students understand when measures of one quantity are proportional to measures of another quantity.

children.title: Identifying Proportional And Non-Proportional Relationships In Tables
children.teaser: Students use a table to determine whether the relationship between two quantities is proportional.

children.title: Identifying Proportional And Non-Proportional Relationships In Tables (continued)
children.teaser: Students understand what makes a relationship proportional or not.

children.title: Identify Proportional and Non-Proportional Relationships In Graphs
children.teaser: Students explore how proportional relationships behave on a graph.

children.title: Identify Proportional and Non-Proportional Relationships In Graphs (continued)
children.teaser: Students identify graphs that show proportional and non-proportional relationships.

children.title: Unit Rate and Constant of Proportionality
children.teaser: Students identify the constant of proportionality by finding unit rate in collection of equivalent ratios.

children.title: Unit Rate as the Constant of Proportionality
children.teaser: Students find and interpret the constant of proportionality within the contexts of problems.

children.title: Representing Proportional Relationships with Equations
children.teaser: Students relate the equations to a corresponding ratio table and/or graphical representation.

children.title: Representing Proportional Relationships with Equations (Continued)
children.teaser: Students understand the structure of proportional relationship equations.

children.title: Interpreting Graphs of Proportional Relationships
children.teaser: Identify and interpret the point (1,r) on the graph of a proportional relationship.

children.title: Ratios and Rates Involving Fractions
children.teaser: Students use ratio tables to reason through and validate their computations of rate.

children.title: Ratios of Fractions and Their Unit Rates
children.teaser: Students work to solve a problem while sharing their thinking processes, strategies, and solutions.

children.title: Ratios of Fractions and Their Unit Rates (Continued)
children.teaser: Students discover how unit rates with fractions can be applied in the real world.

children.title: Finding Equivalent Ratios Given the Total Quantity
children.teaser: Students use tables to find an equivalent ratio of two partial quantities.

children.title: Multi-Step Ratio Problems
children.teaser: Students solve multi-step ratio problems including fractional markdowns, markups, commissions, and fees.

children.title: Equations of Graphs of Proportional Relationships Involving Fractions
children.teaser: Students use equations and graphs to represent proportions arising from ratios and rates involving fractions.

children.title: Ratios of Scale Drawings
children.teaser: Students determine if drawings are areduction or enlargement of a two-dimensional picture.

children.title: Relating Scale Drawings to Ratios and Rates
children.teaser: Students understand a scale drawing is the reduction or the enlargement of a two-dimensional picture.

children.title: The Unit Rate as the Scale Factor
children.teaser: Students recognize the scale factor to be the constant of proportionality.

children.title: Computing Actual Lengths from a Scale Drawing
children.teaser: Given a scale drawing, students compute the lengths in the actual picture using the scale.

children.title: Computing Actual Areas from a Scale Drawing (Continued)
children.teaser: Students identify the scale factor.

children.title: An Exercise in Creating a Scale Drawing
children.teaser: Students create their own scale drawing.

children.title: An Exercise in Changing Scales
children.teaser: Given a scale drawing, students produce a scale drawing of a different scale.

children.title: An Exercise in Changing Scales (Continued)
children.teaser: Students compute the scale factor for the original drawing of a different scale.

children.title: Rational Numbers
children.teaser: Students build on their understanding of rational numbers to add, subtract, multiply, and divide numbers.

children.title: Addition and Subtraction of Integers and Rational Numbers
children.teaser: Students establish rules regarding addition and subtraction of rational numbers.

children.title: Opposite Quantities Combine to Make Zero
children.teaser: Students play the Integer Game, justifying that an integer plus its opposite add to zero.

children.title: Using the Number Line to Model the Addition of Integers
children.teaser: Students recognize that the length of an arrow on the number line is the absolute value.

children.title: Understanding Addition of Integers
children.teaser: Students use arrows to show the sum of two integers, also showing the sum is distance.

children.title: Efficiently Adding Integers and Other Rational Numbers
children.teaser: Students understand the rules for adding integers.

children.title: Understanding Subtraction of Integers and Other Rational Numbers
children.teaser: Students understand the rules for subtracting integers.

children.title: The Distance Between Two Rational Numbers
children.teaser: Students solve word problems involving changes in distance or temperature.

children.title: Addition and Subtraction of Rational Numbers
children.teaser: Students recognize that the rules for adding and subtracting integers apply to rational numbers.

children.title: Applying Properties of Operations to Add and Subtract Rational Numbers
children.teaser: Students use properties of operations to add and subtract rational numbers without a calculator.

children.title: Applying Properties of Operations to Add and Subtract Rational Numbers (Continued)
children.teaser: Students recognize that properties of operations allow us to add and subtract rational numbers more efficiently.

children.title: Multiplication and Division of Integers and Rational Numbers
children.teaser: Students develop the rules for multiplying and dividing signed numbers.

children.title: Understanding Multiplication of Integers
children.teaser: Students practice and justify their understanding of multiplication of integers by using the Integer Game.

children.title: Develop Rules for Multiplying Signed Numbers
children.teaser: Students use the rules for multiplication of signed numbers and give real-world examples.

children.title: Division of Integers
children.teaser: Students recognize that division is the reverse process of multiplication.

children.title: Converting Between Fractions and Decimals Using Equivalent Fractions
children.teaser: Students understand that decimals specify points on the number line by repeatedly subdividing intervals into tenths.

children.title: Converting Rational Numbers to Decimals Using Long Division
children.teaser: Students interpret word problems and convert between fraction and decimal forms of rational numbers.

children.title: Multiplication and Division of Rational Numbers
children.teaser: Students recognize that the rules for multiplying and dividing integers apply to rational numbers.

children.title: Applying Properties of Operations to Multiply and Divide Rational Numbers
children.teaser: Students use commutative and associative properties of multiplication to generate equivalent expressions.

children.title: Applying Operations with Rational Numbers to Expressions and Equations
children.teaser: Students problem-solve with rational numbers and draw upon their prior work with expressions and equations.

children.title: Comparing Tape Diagram Solutions to Algebraic Solutions
children.teaser: Students use tape diagrams to solve equations of the form px+q=r and p(x+q)=r

children.title: Writing, Evaluating, and Finding Equivalent Expressions with Rational Numbers
children.teaser: Students create equivalent forms of expressions.

children.title: Writing, Evaluating, and Finding Equivalent Expressions with Rational Numbers (Continued)
children.teaser: Students recognize structure in equivalent forms of expressions.

children.title: Investments‚ÄîPerforming Operations with Rational Numbers
children.teaser: Students recognize and use mathematics as a tool to solve real-life problems.

children.title: If‚ÄìThen Moves with Integer Number Cards
children.teaser: Students understand the properties of equalities in number sentences.

children.title: Solving Equations Using Algebra
children.teaser: Students identify and compare the sequence of operations used to find solution to equations algebraically.

children.title: Solving Equations Using Algebra (Continued)
children.teaser: Students identify and compare the sequence of operations to find solution to an equation algebraically.

children.title: Expressions and Equations
children.teaser: Students apply properties of operations to solve expressions, equations, and inequalities including geometry problems.

children.title: Use Properties of Operations to Generate Equivalent Expressions
children.teaser: Students extend their understanding of properties of operations and expressions.

children.title: Generating Equivalent Expressions
children.teaser: Students discover the importance of order of operations in generating equivalent expressions.

children.title: Generating Equivalent Expressions (Continued)
children.teaser: Students understand why any order, any grouping works with certain operations and not with others.

children.title: Writing Products as Sums and Sums as Products
children.teaser: Students discover how expressions in different forms can reveal how quantities are related.

children.title: Writing Products as Sums and Sums as Products (Continued)
children.teaser: Students understand the process for writing products as sums and sums as products.

children.title: Using the Identity and Inverse to Write Equivalent Expressions
children.teaser: Students rewrite numerical expressions recalling the definitions of opposites and reciprocals.

children.title: Collecting Rational Number Like Terms
children.teaser: Students write expressions in standard form.

children.title: Solve Problems Using Expressions, Equations, and Inequalities
children.teaser: Students use linear equations and inequalities to solve problems.

children.title: Understanding Equations
children.teaser: Students build an equation that can be used to solve a word problem.

children.title: Using If-Then Moves in Solving Equations
children.teaser: Students transition from using arithmetic, to using algebra to solve the same word problem.

children.title: Using If-Then Moves in Solving Equations (Continued)
children.teaser: Students examine and interpret the structure between ùëùùë• + ùëû = ùëü and ùëù(ùë• + ùëû) = ùëü.

children.title: Angle Problems and Solving Equations
children.teaser: Students describe an angle relationship and set up and solve an equation that models it.

children.title: Angle Problems and Solving Equations (Continued)
children.teaser: Students apply their understanding of equations to unknown angle problems.

children.title: Properties of Inequalities
children.teaser: Students practice their knowledge of solving linear equations.

children.title: Inequalities
children.teaser: Students explore the ‚Äúwhy‚Äù and ‚Äúhow‚Äù of moving from numerical expressions to algebraic inequalities.

children.title: Solving Inequalities
children.teaser: Students interpret inequality solutions in the context of the problem.

children.title: Graphing Solutions to Inequalities
children.teaser: Students practice their knowledge of solving linear inequalities

children.title: Use Equations and Inequalities to Solve Geometry Problems
children.teaser: Students use equations and expressions to study area, perimeter, surface area, and volume.

children.title: The Most Famous Ratio of All
children.teaser: Students develop the definition of a circle using diameter and radius.

children.title: The Area of a Circle
children.teaser: Students use the formula for the area of a circle to solve problems.

children.title: More Problems on Area and Circumference
children.teaser: Students examine the meaning of quarter circle and semicircle.

children.title: Unknown Area Problems on the Coordinate Plane
children.teaser: Students extend their knowledge of finding area to figures on a coordinate plane.

children.title: Composite Area Problems
children.teaser: Students find composite areas of regions in the coordinate plane.

children.title: Surface Area
children.teaser: Students find the surface area of three-dimensional objects.

children.title: Surface Area (Continued)
children.teaser: Students discover strategies for finding the surface area of solids.

children.title: The Volume of a Right Prism
children.teaser: Students use the known formula for the volume of a right rectangular prism.

children.title: The Volume of a Right Prism (Continued)
children.teaser: Students compute volumes of right prisms involving fractional values for length.

children.title: Volume and Surface Area
children.teaser: Students solve real-world volume and surface area problems.

children.title: Volume and Surface Area (Continued)
children.teaser: Students solve real-world problems and present their approaches for determining volume and surface area.

children.title: Percent and Proportional Relationships
children.teaser: Students deepen their understanding of ratios and proportions by solving a variety of percent problems.

children.title: Finding the Whole
children.teaser: Students represent percents as decimals and fractions.

children.title: Percent
children.teaser: Students write a non-whole number percent as a complex fraction.

children.title: Part of a Whole as a Percent
children.teaser: Students solve word problems involving percent using expressions, equations, and numeric and visual models.

children.title: Comparing Quantities with Percent
children.teaser: Students use context of a word problem to determine which quantity represents the whole.

children.title: Percent Increase and Decrease
children.teaser: Students solve percent problems involving a percent increase or decrease.

children.title: Finding One Hundred Percent Given Another Percent
children.teaser: Students solve word problems involving finding 100% of a given quantity.

children.title: Fluency with Percents
children.teaser: Students solve percent problems by identifying the type of problem and applying strategies.

children.title: Percent Problems Including More Than One Whole
children.teaser: Students apply their understanding of percent and proportions to solve real-world problems.

children.title: Markup and Markdown Problems
children.teaser: Students understand the terms original price, selling price, markup, markdown, markup rate, and markdown rate.

children.title: Percent Error Problems
children.teaser: Students understand the meaning of percent error.

children.title: Problem Solving When the Percent Changes
children.teaser: Students solve percent problems where quantities and percents change.

children.title: Simple Interest
children.teaser: Students solve simple interest problems

children.title: Tax, Commissions, Fees, and Other Real-World Percent Problems
children.teaser: Students solve real-world percent problems involving tax, gratuities, commissions, and fees.

children.title: Scale Drawings
children.teaser: Students  solve problems in which the scale factor is represented by a percent.

children.title: The Scale Factor as a Percent for a Scale Drawing
children.teaser: Students make scale drawings in which the horizontal and vertical scales are different.

children.title: Changing Scales
children.teaser: Students find missing scale factor.

children.title: Computing Actual Lengths from a Scale Drawing
children.teaser: Given a scale drawing, students compute the lengths in the actual picture using the scale factor.

children.title: Solving Area Problems Using Scale Drawings
children.teaser: Students solve area problems related to scale drawings and percent.

children.title: Population, Mixture, and Counting Problems Involving Percents
children.teaser: Students apply understanding of percent to solve complex word problems .

children.title: Population Problems
children.teaser: Students apply understanding of percents to problems involving populations.

children.title: Mixture Problems
children.teaser: Students use their knowledge of percent to complete charts and answer mixture problems.

children.title: Counting Problems
children.teaser: Students solve counting problems related to computing percents.

children.title: Statistics and Probability
children.teaser: Students calculate estimate and interpret probabilities, collect random samples, estimate population characteristics, and compare populations.

children.title: Calculating and Interpreting Probabilities
children.teaser: Students learn to compute or estimate probabilities using a variety of methods.

children.title: Chance Experiments
children.teaser: Students understand that a probability represents the likelihood that an event will occur.

children.title: Estimating Probabilities by Collecting Data
children.teaser: Students use given data to estimate probabilities.

children.title: Chance Experiments with Equally Likely Outcomes
children.teaser: Students determine the possible outcomes for simple chance experiments.

children.title: Calculating Probabilities for Chance Experiments with Equally Likely Outcomes
children.teaser: Students conduct chance experiments that have equally likely outcomes.

children.title: Chance Experiments with Outcomes That Are Not Equally Likely
children.teaser: Students understand that outcomes are not always equally likely.

children.title: Using Tree Diagrams Representing a Sample Space to Calculate Probabilities
children.teaser: Students draw tree diagrams to calculate probabilities of compound events.

children.title: Calculating Probabilities of Compound Events
children.teaser: Students calculate probabilities of compound events.

children.title: Estimating Probabilities
children.teaser: Students compare probabilities from simulations to computed probabilities based on theoretical models.

children.title: The Difference Between Theoretical Probabilities and Estimated Probabilities
children.teaser: Students distinguish between theoretical probabilities and estimated probabilities.

children.title: Comparing Estimated Probabilities to Probabilities Predicted by a Model
children.teaser: Students compare estimated probabilities to those predicted by a probability model.

children.title: Conducting a Simulation to Estimate the Probability of an Event
children.teaser: Students learn how to perform simulations to estimate probabilities.

children.title: Conducting a Simulation to Estimate the  Probability of an Event (Continued)
children.teaser: Students design their own simulations.

children.title: Applying Probability to Make Informed Decisions
children.teaser: Students use estimated probabilities to make informed decisions.

children.title: Random Sampling and Estimating Population Characteristics
children.teaser: Students investigate sampling from a population.

children.title: Populations, Samples, and Generalizing from a Sample to a Population
children.teaser: Students differentiate between a population and a sample.

children.title: Selecting a Sample
children.teaser: Students begin to think about how to choose a sample.

children.title: Random Sampling
children.teaser: Students investigate how random samples from the same population vary.

children.title: Methods for Selecting a Random Sample
children.teaser: Students select a random sample from a population.

children.title: Sampling Variability
children.teaser: Students use data from a random number table to estimate a population mean.

children.title: Sampling Variability and the Effect of Sample Size
children.teaser: Students use data from a random sample to estimate a population mean.

children.title: Understanding Variability When Estimating a Population Proportion
children.teaser: Students investigate sampling variability in the sample proportion for categorical data.

children.title: Estimating a Population Proportion
children.teaser: Students use data from a random sample to estimate a population proportion.

children.title: Comparing Populations
children.teaser: Students learn to compare two populations with similar variability.

children.title: Why Worry About Sampling Variability?
children.teaser: Students compare the means of two populations.

children.title: Comparing Two or More Populations with Sample Data (Complete)
children.teaser: Students express the difference in sample means as a multiple of a measure of variability.

children.title: Comparing Two or More Populations with Sample Data
children.teaser: Students decide whether two population means are similar or different.

children.title: Geometry
children.teaser: Students extend knowledge of geometry topics including: angles, area, surface area, and volume.

children.title: Unknown Angles
children.teaser: Students use a synthesis of angle relationships and algebra to solve unknown angle problems.

children.title: Complementary and Supplementary Angles
children.teaser: Students solve for unknown angles involving complementary and supplementary angles.

children.title: Solving for Unknown Angles Using Equations
children.teaser: Students solve for unknown angles involving complementary, supplementary, vertical, adjacent angles.

children.title: Solving for Unknown Angles Using Equations (Continued...)
children.teaser: Students solve for unknown angles in word problems and in diagrams involving all learned angle facts.

children.title: Solving for Unknown Angles Using Equations (Continued)
children.teaser: Students solve an equation for the unknown angle based on relevant angle relationships.

children.title: Constructing Triangles
children.teaser: Students construct geometric shapes (mainly triangles).

children.title: Identical Triangles
children.teaser: Students use a triangle correspondence to recognize when two triangles match identically.

children.title: Drawing Geometric Shapes
children.teaser: Students use a compass, protractor, and ruler to draw geometric shapes based on given conditions.

children.title: Drawing Parallelograms
children.teaser: Students use a protractor, ruler, and setsquare to draw parallelograms.

children.title: Drawing Triangles
children.teaser: Students understand how a triangle is put together under given conditions.

children.title: Conditions for Unique Triangle‚ÄïThree Sides Two Sides and Included Angle
children.teaser: Students draw all variations of a triangle with all three side lengths provided.

children.title: Conditions for a Unique Triangle‚ÄïTwo Angles and a Given Side
children.teaser: Students learn to identify the conditions that determine a unique triangle.

children.title: Conditions on Measurements That Determine a Triangle
children.teaser: Students understand two angle measurements determine many triangles (provided angle sum is less than 180¬∞)

children.title: Unique Triangles‚ÄîTwo Sides and a Non-Included Angle
children.teaser: Students learn to identify the conditions that do and do not determine a unique triangle.

children.title: Checking for Identical Triangles
children.teaser: Students use conditions that determine a unique triangle to determine when two triangles are identical.

children.title: Checking for Identical Triangles (Continued)
children.teaser: Students use information to establish whether conditions that determine a unique triangle exist.

children.title: Using Unique Triangles to Solve Real-World and Mathematical Problems
children.teaser: Students determine if triangles are identical and show how this leads to further conclusions about the diagram.

children.title: Slicing Solids
children.teaser: Students are introduced to the idea of a slice, or cross section, of a three-dimensional figure.

children.title: Slicing a Right Rectangular Prism with a Plane
children.teaser: Students examine slices made parallel or perpendicular to a face of a solid.

children.title: Slicing a Right Rectangular Pyramid with a Plane
children.teaser: Students build pyramids from nets while studying the formal definition of pyramid.

children.title: Slicing on an Angle
children.teaser: Students examine slices that are not parallel/perpendicular to a base or face.

children.title: Understanding Three-Dimensional Figures
children.teaser: Students examine figures built out of unit cubes.

children.title: Problems Involving Area and Surface Area
children.teaser: Students explore surface area of three-dimensional figures.

children.title: Real-World Area Problems
children.teaser: Students apply understanding of the area of polygons and circular regions to real-world contexts.

children.title: Mathematical Area Problems
children.teaser: Students use area models to make an explicit connection between area and algebraic expressions.

children.title: Area Problems with Circular Regions
children.teaser: Students find area of composite figures and of missing regions.

children.title: Surface Area: 3D
children.teaser: Students find surface area of three-dimensional figures.

children.title: Surface Area: 3D (Continued)
children.teaser: Students find surface area of figures with missing sections.

children.title: Problems Involving Volume
children.teaser: Students explore volume of three-dimensional figures.

children.title: Volume of Right Prisms
children.teaser: Students multiply the area base and height of the prism to find volume.

children.title: Volume of Composite Three-Dimensional Objects
children.teaser: Students compare different methods to determine composite volume.

children.title: Real-World Volume Problems
children.teaser: Students apply knowledge of volume to real-world contexts involving rate of flow of liquid.
